subject: Home & DIY
title: The Birth of the Skyscraper
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Birth of the Skyscraper.

hook.text: Chicago's Home Insurance Building opened in 1885 at just 10 stories. It's considered the world's first skyscraper.

buildup.text: Traditional buildings used load-bearing wallsâ€”the taller you went, the thicker the ground-floor walls had to be.

discovery.text: William Le Baron Jenney used a steel skeleton frame, letting the walls hang like curtains instead of bearing weight.

twist.text: Without Elisha Otis's safety elevator from 1852, nobody would have rented offices above the fifth floor.

climax.text: Steel frame plus elevator equaled unlimited height. Within 30 years, Manhattan's skyline was unrecognizable.

punchline.text: Buildings grew tall when walls stopped working.

quiz.question: What structural innovation made the first skyscraper possible?
options: A steel skeleton frame instead of load-bearing walls
